systems.name: WordPress.org
systems.support: Open source; maintained by the WordPress community; backed by the WordPress Foundation and Automattic; widely supported by most hosting companies.
systems.technology: PHP-based CMS running on a LAMP/LEMP stack (Linux, Apache/Nginx, MySQL/MariaDB, PHP); themes and plugins render HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.
systems.capabilities: Massive ecosystem of themes and plugins; built-in blogging and CMS features; Gutenberg block editor for page building; REST API for headless or custom integrations; good SEO support through plugins; multi-user roles and permissions.
systems.limitations: Security depends heavily on keeping core, themes, and plugins updated; third-party plugins can introduce vulnerabilities; performance can degrade without caching/optimization; requires more ongoing maintenance than SaaS builders.

systems.name: Drupal
systems.support: Open source; maintained by the Drupal community; commercial support available from vendors like Acquia.
systems.technology: PHP framework/CMS using a modular architecture; typically runs on LAMP/LEMP with MySQL/MariaDB or PostgreSQL; uses Twig for templating.
systems.capabilities: Highly flexible content modeling with custom content types and fields; enterprise-grade security and regular security advisories; advanced role-based access control (ACL); multilingual support built in; very scalable for large and high-traffic sites; strong API support and integration options.
systems.limitations: Steeper learning curve for non-developers; fewer plug-and-play themes compared with WordPress; upgrades between major versions can be complex; heavy use of modules can impact performance if not optimized.

systems.name: Joomla
systems.support: Open source; managed by the Joomla Project and Open Source Matters with a global volunteer community.
systems.technology: PHP-based CMS using an MVC architecture; usually runs on LAMP/LEMP with MySQL/MariaDB; templates built with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.
systems.capabilities: Integrated Access Control List (ACL) for granular permissions; multilingual support in core; flexible template and extension system; good for portals and more complex sites; supports modules, components, and plugins for extensibility.
systems.limitations: Smaller extension and theme ecosystem than WordPress; extension quality and maintenance can vary; admin UI can feel less friendly for beginners; fewer turnkey managed hosting options and tutorials compared with WordPress.

systems.name: Squarespace
systems.support: Commercial SaaS platform; fully hosted and supported by Squarespace with subscription plans.
systems.technology: Proprietary hosted platform; no direct database or server access; templates rendered with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript through the Squarespace editor and template system.
systems.capabilities: All-in-one hosting and CMS; drag-and-drop visual editor; professionally designed responsive templates; built-in blogging, basic ecommerce, and SEO tools; automatic updates, backups, and security handled by the vendor; no need to manage servers.
systems.limitations: Limited back-end customization; cannot install custom server-side code or use your own database; design options are constrained by the template system; content and page limits on some plans; limited multilingual features compared with open-source CMS; ongoing subscription costs and vendor lock-in.

systems.name: Wix
systems.support: Commercial SaaS platform; fully hosted and supported by Wix with free and premium plans.
systems.technology: Proprietary website builder; drag-and-drop editor with optional Velo (JavaScript) for custom logic; content stored in Wix CMS collections on Wixâ€™s infrastructure.
systems.capabilities: Very easy visual editing with many templates; built-in blog and ecommerce tools; app market for adding marketing, booking, and analytics features; Wix CMS collections for dynamic content; hosting, security, and updates managed by Wix.
systems.limitations: Sites run on shared hosting with limited low-level performance tuning; vendor lock-in and limited ability to export a full site to another platform; CMS collections and item counts are limited by plan; advanced customization and SEO tuning can be harder than on fully self-hosted platforms.
